stem: The nurse is reviewing the medication administration history for a client with Type 1 Diabetes. Based on the pharmaceutical data, match each insulin type with the period during which the client is at the highest risk for hypoglycemia.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:30: Client (24y/o female) reports feeling 'shaky' and 'sweaty' 4 hours after her morning NPH dose. 
08:00: Client received 5 units of Insulin Lispro with breakfast. 
12:00: Blood glucose is 62 mg/dL. 
18:00: Client received Insulin NPH and Insulin Regular before dinner. 
22:00: Client received Insulin Glargine for basal coverage.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: At 12:30: HR 118, BP 138/84, Diaphoretic, Tremors noted in bilateral hands.

columns.text: Steady risk: No pronounced peak (24-hour delivery)

rationale.correct: Hypoglycemia risk is highest during the insulin's PEAK. Rapid-acting (Lispro) peaks in 30-90 mins (c1). Short-acting (Regular) peaks in 2-4 hours (c2). Intermediate-acting (NPH) peaks in 4-12 hours (c3). Long-acting (Glargine) is peakless (c4). The flowsheet shows hypoglycemia at 12:30, which is roughly 4-5 hours after the NPH dose, indicating an NPH-related peak drop.
clinicalPearls: Always feed the patient when the insulin is peaking.
Rapid-Acting: Give with the tray in front of the patient.
If a patient gets NPH at 08:00, their mid-afternoon snack (at peak time) is critical to prevent low blood sugar.

questionTrap.trap: Believing that Regular insulin is 'Rapid' because it starts fast.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'Regular is Short'. Lispro/Aspart are 'Rapid'. Rapid is faster than Short!
